title: How Weather Affects MG

content: Living with myasthenia gravis (MG) is like trying to predict the weather—unpredictable and sometimes downright frustrating.

One of the biggest challenges I face is how weather affects my symptoms. Here in the U.K., we usually don’t have to worry about extreme heat, but even a warm day can leave me feeling more tired and drained. That’s why I’m careful to plan my day around the forecast, doing what I need to do early before temps rise too much.
But things really get interesting when I travel abroad to hotter climates.

When I’m in a hot country, the heat can hit me hard. My muscles feel weaker, and I get fatigued much faster. Walking through a sun-drenched street can feel like trekking through the desert. I’ve learned to pack strategically. Cooling towels, light clothes, plenty of water, and a plan to avoid the midday sun are all musts. It can be a real challenge, especially in those first few days when my body is adjusting.

content: But here’s the strange part. While heat makes my symptoms worse initially, I actually feel more energized with time. I think it has to do with getting more vitamin D from the sun. There’s something about soaking up sunshine that seems to give me a boost, almost like my body is thanking me for it. It’s a bit of a paradox—feeling worse at first, but then better overall after a few days.

This experience taught me that while I have to be cautious in the heat, there are benefits to getting out there and enjoying the sunshine in moderation. I find the key is balance, making sure I don’t overdo it but taking the time to get that natural vitamin D. It plays a big role in keeping my energy levels up.
It’s another reminder of how complex living with MG can be and how important it is to listen to my body.

Cold weather isn’t exactly a walk in the park either. While it doesn’t hit me with the same immediate fatigue that heat does, it brings its own set of challenges. When it’s cold, your body starts to shiver to generate heat. Shivering might seem like a minor inconvenience, but for someone with MG, it’s more than that.

content: Shivering involves rapid, involuntary muscle contractions. When your muscles are already compromised, this extra activity can be incredibly taxing. It can lead to quicker fatigue and increased weakness, turning what might seem like a minor chill into something much more draining.

To deal with the cold, I’ve learned to wear layers and stay as warm as possible to keep my muscles from overworking just to stay warm. It’s another reminder of how MG forces you to be constantly aware of your body’s needs and how something as simple as weather can change everything.

Despite these challenges, I find that living with MG makes me more in tune with the world around me. I pay attention to the subtleties of the weather in a way I never did before. I’ve learned to adapt, to be flexible, and plan ahead. And while I might not be able to control the weather, I’ve found ways to work with it rather than against it.

content: Traveling to warmer climates, or even dealing with the unpredictability of the U.K. weather, taught me the importance of being prepared and listening to my body. It’s not always easy, and there are days I wish I didn’t have to think about any of this.
But in the end, these experiences have made me more resilient. I take pride in the small victories, like getting through a hot day with minimal discomfort or finding joy in a brisk and chilly walk.
